hypotheses: Nations with efficient governments tend to show lower COVID-19 infection and mortality rates.
Tight cultural norms are associated with better COVID-19 outcomes.
claim.hypotheses_location: Results section, discussing regression analysis outcomes (page 10)
claim.statement: Nations with efficient governments and tight cultural norms have better outcomes in terms of limiting both infection and mortality rates associated with COVID-19.
claim.statement_location: Introduction section, overview of study’s objective (page 1)

data.source: COVID-19 case and death statistics from 141 nations
data.access_details: Data and code are provided online
data.notes: Used World Bank’s Government Efficiency Index and cultural tightness index by Gelfand et al.

method.description: The study conducted regression analyses to assess how cultural tightness and government efficiency influenced COVID-19 infection and mortality rates globally, while controlling for GDP, Gini coefficient, and median age.
steps: Collect COVID-19 case and death data from 141 nations.
Measure infection rates (cases/million) and mortality likelihood (deaths/confirmed cases).
Evaluate government efficiency using World Bank index.
Assess cultural tightness using Gelfand et al.'s index.
Perform regression analyses controlling for GDP, Gini, and median age.
Interpret coefficients for cultural tightness and government efficiency.
method.models: Robust regression; logistic regression for mortality likelihood
method.outcome_variable: COVID-19 infection rates and mortality likelihood
method.control_variables: GDP per capita, Gini coefficient, median age

results.summary: Higher cultural tightness and government efficiency were associated with significantly lower COVID-19 infection and mortality rates.

metadata.original_paper_title: Cultural and Institutional Influences on COVID-19 Outcomes
